text: Monocytes are produced in the bone marrow and circulate in blood for 24-48 hours [ 1 ] .
In the absence of serum , monocytes die via apoptosis [ 1 ] , [ 2 ] .
Macrophage colony-stimulating factor ( M-CSF ) stimulates mononuclear phagocyte survival and differentiation [ 3 ] .

Importantly , M-CSF - mediated cell survival and activation is associated with a variety of human diseases , including atherosclerosis , transplant vascular sclerosis and breast cancer metastasis [ 4 ] , [ 5 ] , [ 6 ] .
We previously identified that NF-kappaB activation is important in M-CSF - induced monocyte survival [ 7 ] .

In addition to its role in mononuclear phagocyte survival , the transcription factor NF-kappaB regulates numerous genes that play important roles in cellular signaling , stress response , cell growth , survival , differentiation and inflammation [ 8 ] .

There are five members in the NF-kappaB family : <extra_id_0> RelA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> p50 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> p52 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> c-Rel <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> RelB <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

The most common activating complex is the <extra_id_0> p50 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> heterodimer , driven by the activation domain in the NF-kappaB <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> subunit .
NF-kappaB <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> regulates important developmental processes [ 9 ] , [ 10 ] .
Mice lacking NF-kappaB <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> die in utero and have extensive liver damage via enhanced apoptosis [ 9 ] .

Embryonic macrophages from NF-kappaB <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> null mice are susceptible to <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced apoptosis which is rescued by overexpressing the NF-kappaB <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> subunit [ 10 ] .

text: Moreover , inhibiting NF-kappaB induces cell death in many cell types and cytokine - independent survival is mediated by constitutively active NF-kappaB in murine macrophages [ 11 ] .
In monocytes and macrophages , NF-kappaB is an important transcriptional factor for expression of cytokines and cell surface receptors [ 12 ] .

However , unlike resting T-cells , NF-kappaB is constitutively present in the nuclei of primary monocytes and monocytic cell lines in the absence of exogenous stimuli as demonstrated by mobility shift analysis [ 13 ] .
Similarly , constitutively active NF-kappaB was observed in human alveolar macrophages [ 14 ] .

In the classic / canonical pathway , the NF-kappaB <extra_id_0> p50 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> complex is sequestered in the cytosol by <extra_id_0> IkappaBalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 15 ] .

Upon stimulation by cytokines or UV radiation , <extra_id_0> IkappaBalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is phosphorylated , ubiquitinated , and degraded , releasing NF-kappaB <extra_id_0> p50 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> to translocate to the nucleus and transactivate target genes .

Previous research shows that phosphorylation of NF-kappaB <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> at Ser276 , Ser529 or Ser536 plays an important role in regulating transcriptional activity of NF-kappaB [ 17 ] .

text: Several other phosphorylation sites are also described to enhance NF-kappaB gene transactivation [ 25 ] .
Here , we investigate the role of protein kinase C ( PKC ) in M-CSF - stimulated NF-kappaB activation .
PKC proteins are multifunctional kinases that differ in structure , function and co-factor requirement [ 26 ] .
PKCs are involved in diverse cell responses , including cell growth , survival , differentiation and development [ 27 ] .

The 12 closely related enzymes of the PKC family are divided into three classes : conventional ( cPKCs : <extra_id_0> alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> <extra_id_0> betaI <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> <extra_id_0> betaII <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> require Ca2+ and diacylglycerol ( DAG ) ; novel ( nPKCs : <extra_id_0> delta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> epsilon <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> eta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> theta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> mu <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) require DAG ; and atypical ( aPKCs : <extra_id_0> xi <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> iota <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> lambda <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) require neither Ca2+ nor DAG .

Monocytes and macrophages predominantly express conventional PKC isoforms ( <extra_id_0> PKCalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> <extra_id_0> PKCbetaI <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> PKCbetaII <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) and novel PKCs ( <extra_id_0> PKCdelta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> PKCepsilon <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) .
Conventional PKCs regulate differentiation of the human promyelocytic leukemia cell line HL60 to macrophages [ 28 ] .

text: In addition , accumulating evidence suggests that conventional PKCs like <extra_id_0> PKCalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> have anti-apoptotic functions .
For example , <extra_id_0> PKCalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is overexpressed in a variety of tumor cells including gliomas , liver , and lung [ 30 ] , [ 31 ] .
In epithelial cells , inhibition of <extra_id_0> PKCalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> induces <extra_id_0> PKCdelta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - dependent apoptosis [ 31 ] .

Interestingly , in human monocytes and premonocytic THP-1 leukemia cells , novel PKCs like <extra_id_0> PKCdelta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> have the opposite effect on cell survival , Voss et al showed that <extra_id_0> PKCdelta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> directly phosphorylates <extra_id_0> caspase-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and promotes etoposide - induced apoptosis [ 32 ] .

text: Moreover , knockout mouse studies suggest that another novel PKC , <extra_id_0> PKCepsilon <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is critically involved in early LPS - mediated signaling in activated macrophages [ 33 ] .
Previously , we reported that M-CSF promotes monocyte survival through the activation of the PI3-K / AKT pathway [ 3 ] .
In addition to AKT activation , M-CSF stimulates PKC in human monocytes and increases NF-kappaB DNA binding [ 34 ] .
However , whether PKC and / or NF-kappaB activation is critical in M-CSF - stimulated mononuclear phagocyte survival and / or differentiation is unclear .

In other cells , PKC plays an important role in NF-kappaB activation and cell survival [ 35 ] , however the specific mechanisms of this activation and the biological effects on cellular phenotype are not known .
Therefore , we focused at understanding the role of PKC in the regulation of NF-kappaB activation and M-CSF - induced monocyte survival .
Here we demonstrates that M-CSF upregulated the NF-kappaB transcription and cell survival in human and mouse macrophages .

This activity was reduced by the conventional , but not novel , PKC inhibitors , <extra_id_0> dominant negative PKCalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> constructs or <extra_id_0> PKCalpha siRNA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

Conventional PKC regulated NF-kappaB - regulated gene expression and phosphorylation of Ser276 of NF-kappaB <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> occurred in an M-CSF - dependent fashion correlating with its maximal transcriptional activity .
